moves.1. e4:
Me against a friend of mine. Claude Vullivux Kladninsky who plays very sharp in his openings.
Played 12 November 2006. We have ECF grades. So here we go. 1.e4 what I nearly always play.
moves.2. d4 d5 3. Nd2: Tarrach variation which I like to play.
moves.3... Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. Bd3 c5 6. c3 Nc6: ? I shouldn't of played that because I should of done Ne2.
moves.7... Qa5 8. Bd2 Qb6 9. Qb3 cxd4 10. Qxb6: ! Strong move. If the bishop moves away from the b1 and h7 diagonal then Nc2  and winning a rook. If I move it away from f1 and a6 diagonal. Then Nc4 and then Knights can be well placed.
moves.12... Bd7 13. Bxd7+ Kxd7: I was to expecting to take with the king.
moves.14. Bxb4 Bxb4+ 15. Nd2 Nc4: Nc4! He is going to win a pawn.
moves.17... Rac8 18. Rac1: I wanted one of the rooks off.
moves.18... b5 19. h3: ? I should of just change rooks.
moves.20. Rfd1: ?? A very terrible mistake from me. Taking or moving it away was the only option.
moves.22. Rxc1 Bxd2 23. Rc5 a6 24. g4 Rc8: I resigned in this position because he is going to win with extra piece and pawn. Well played Vullivux.

players: Chris Davison (112) vs. Claude Vullivux Klandinsky (116)
